questions.question: AWS CloudShell is free to use.
questions.explanation: CloudShell is free! It provides a browser-based shell with AWS CLI pre-installed and automatically authenticated. No setup or cost required.

questions.question: What is the persistent storage limit for CloudShell per region?
questions.explanation: CloudShell provides 1 GB of persistent storage per region in your home directory. Files you save persist between sessions but are region-specific.

questions.question: What does AWS Cloud9 provide? (Select ALL that apply)
options: Full IDE with code editor and debugger
questions.explanation: Cloud9 provides a full IDE, real-time collaboration, and pre-installed tools. However, it runs on EC2 instances which cost money - Cloud9 itself is free but the underlying compute isn't.

questions.question: Match each feature with the appropriate tool:
questions.explanation: CloudShell is best for quick CLI work and is free. Cloud9 is better for full development, Docker, and long-running tasks but costs money (EC2).

questions.question: How can you avoid unexpected costs with AWS Cloud9?
options: Use the largest instance type for faster development
Enable auto-stop to shutdown after idle time
Cloud9 is free, there are no costs to manage
Delete the Cloud9 IDE after each session
questions.explanation: Enable auto-stop (automatic shutdown after idle time) to avoid paying for EC2 when not actively using Cloud9. The default is 30 minutes of idle time.

questions.question: You must run 'aws configure' in CloudShell to set up credentials before using AWS CLI commands.
questions.explanation: CloudShell is automatically authenticated with your console credentials. No setup required - just open CloudShell and start running commands immediately.
